attributes.title: Personal Safety Anxiety And Vigilance: Testing an Expanded Model of Objectification Theory

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Expanded Objectification Theory Model SEM Replication Study

sample.value: Approximately 500 participants will participate in a study of Personal and Social Wellness. Participants must be 18 or over, female-identified, and English-speaking to participate. On Prolific, participants must be American and must have an acceptance rate of 95% or above.

analyses.value: We will conduct latent variable structural equation modeling via Mplus Version 6.12 (Muthén & Muthén, 1998-2011) with maximum likelihood estimation to examine whether the hypothesized model in Figure 1 fit the data. For each latent variable, we will create three parcels via the procedure specified by Russell et al. (1998). These parcels will be used to estimate the latent variable. Model fit will be determined once again by consensus among the CFI, SRMR, and RMSEA fit indices (Hu & Bentler, 1999), with values around ≥ .95 for CFI, ≤ .08 for SRMR, and ≤ .06 for RMSEA indicating a relatively good fit, and values well outside of these ranges (i.e., ≤ .90 for CFI,  ≥ .10 for SRMR and RMSEA) indicate a poor fit. We will specify Mplus to create 10,000 bootstrap samples from the data by random sampling with replacement and generate indirect effects to test whether personal safety anxiety functions as an independent mediating mechanism linking experiences of both sexual- and self-objectification with restricted freedom of movement. We will also examine a serial mediation model that links sexual objectification to self-objectification to personal safety anxiety to restricted freedom movement.

outliers.value:
We will assess skewness and kurtosis values of mean scores for each individual scale to insure that no transformations are needed. We will use Bryne's (2010) cutoff values (acceptable range of skewness between ‐2 to +2 and kurtosis is between ‐7 to +7).  

Observations will be excluded if selected gender is other than ‘female', if duplicates cases are identified, the validity question embedded in the survey is answer incorrectly (e.g., “Please respond "infrequently" to this item.”), if terminated early, or had significant missing data (i.e., ≥ 20% of items missing on a given questionnaire).

dependent.value:
- Sexual objectification experiences: 9-item Stranger Harassment Index (Fairchild & Rudman, 2008). 
- Personal safety anxiety: 8-item Personal Safety Anxiety and Vigilance Scale (Calogero et al., 2019). 
- Restricted freedom of movement: 10 items adapted from Fairchild & Rudman (2008). 
- Body shame: 13-item Body-Focused Shame and Guilt Scale (Weingarden, Renshaw, Tangney, & Wilhelm, 2016). 
- Self-objectification: 14-item Self-Objectification Beliefs and Behaviors Scale (SOBBS; Lindner & Tantleff-Dunn, 2017). 
- Social appearance anxiety: 16-item Social Appearance Anxiety Scale (Hart et al., 2008). 
- Depressed mood: 20-item Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale. 
- Sexual functioning: 12-items from the Female Sexual Functioning Index (subscales: desire, arousal, orgasm, satisfaction; Rosen et al., 2000). 
- Interoceptive Awareness: 12 items from The Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness (subscales: noticing, emotional awareness, body listening; Mehling, Price, Daubenmeier, Acree, Bartmess, & Stewart, 2012).
-  Disordered eating: 26-item Eating Attitudes Test (without the "oral" subscale; Garner et al.,1982). 
- Dispositional flow: 9-item Short Dispositional Flow Scale (Jackson, Martin, & Eklund, 2008).
- Fear and risk of rape: 4-item Fear and Risk of Rape Scale (Fairchild & Rudman, 2008).
- Fear of crime: 10-item Fear of Crime Scale (Ferraro, 1995); one item modified ("being approached on the street by a beggar or panhandler" replaced with "being kidnapped")

The first 11 scales will be counterbalanced, followed by the last two scales, which will be counterbalanced with one another.

hypothesis.value: The aim of this study is to replicate the pattern of findings we observed for a comprehensive and expanded objectification theory model that determined the relative importance of the pathways by which both sexual and self-objectification predict each of the subjective experiences, including the novel inclusion of personal safety anxiety, and each of the mental and physical constraints on women’s lived experience, including the novel inclusion of restricted freedom of movement.

q1.value: Moorean and evaluative incoherencies: an experimental approach (Study #2)

q2.value: Andres Soria Ruiz, Nils Franzén, Mora Maldonado

q3.value:
Expressivists in metaethics maintain that moral statements do not serve to describe the world, but that their function instead is to express that the speaker is in a certain conative or affective state of mind. 

The contrast between moral and non-moral statements is sometimes presented as the idea that, whereas non-moral statements express cognitive mental states such as belief, moral statements express non-cognitive mental states, such as approval. Moreover, the latter express non-cognitive states in the same way that non-moral statements express beliefs. This is Schroeder's 'Parity Thesis':

'[M]oral sentences are related to noncognitive, desire‐like states of mind in the same way that ordinary descriptive sentences are related to ordinary beliefs—they express them. (Schroeder, 2008, p. 3). 

The Parity Thesis makes a testable prediction: if moral assertions express non-cognitive attitudes in the same way that non-moral assertions express beliefs, then whatever relations hold between non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions should hold as well between moral assertions and ascriptions of the relevant non-cognitive attitudes. In particular, just as certain combinations of non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions generate so-called Moore paradoxes (1), similar combinations of moral assertions and ascriptions of non-cognitive attitudes ought to generate analogously unacceptable constructions (2).

(1) Murder is wrong but I don’t think it is wrong.
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.

Woods (2014) claims that this is not the case: sentences like (2) are not unacceptable in the same way that Moorean paradoxes are. He argues that this constitutes a major blow to the Parity Thesis. Woods, however, bases his claim that sentences like (2) are acceptable on his intuitions. But intuitions vary, and not everyone agrees with Woods on this score. 

The purpose of our study is to empirically test the acceptability of sentences like (2), and thereby provide empirical evidence that speaks to Wood's claim, the Parity Thesis, and the connection between moral language and non-cognitive attitudes that is the focus of much contemporary literature on metaethics and philosophy of language.

In a previous study, we tested the acceptability of constructions exactly like (2) (https://osf.io/vwekq/?view_only=d5281af405f54493a67cb3c2759d76ac). In this follow-up study, we will test the acceptability of the following variant of (2): 

(2') Murder is wrong under any circumstance but I don’t disapprove of it under any circumstance.

q4.value:
We have two hypothesis: either sentences like (2') (henceforth 'evaluative incoherencies') are acceptable or they are not.  

To test these hypotheses, we will study the acceptability of statements constructed following this template: where x is an individual-referring term and A is a propositional attitude verb,

Murder is wrong under any circumstance but x does not A {that murder is wrong / murder} under any circumstance

We will manipulate two factors on constructions that follow this template:
(a) Attitude: A will stand for 'think' or 'disapprove of' (thus the variability between assigning a full propositional clause or just a noun)
(b) Person: x will be the speaker ('I') or a third person ('Ann')

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but I don't think that it is wrong under any circumstance.           
(= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but I don’t disapprove of it under any circumstance.                    
(= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong under any circumstance. 
(= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but Ann doesn't disapprove of it under any circumstance.          
(= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Given the type of constructions that we will test, our hypotheses can be spelled out more concretely in the following research questions:

(i) Are sentences like (1)/(2) significantly less acceptable than their third-personal counterparts (3)/(4)? In other words, is the Person factor a good predictor of acceptability of these constructions (modulo potential interactions)?

(ii) Is the difference in acceptability between sentences like (1) and (3) similar to the difference in acceptability between sentences like (2) and (4)? That is, is there an interaction between the Person and Attitude factors?

(iii) How does the acceptability of (2') differ from that of (2)?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
We have a within-subjects design with 2 factors: Person (levels: first/third) and Attitude (levels: think/disapprove).  The combination of these two factors gives rise to four sentence configurations, repeated in (1-4) below from above:

(1) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but I don't think that it is wrong under any circumstance.           
(= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but I don’t disapprove of it under any circumstance.                    
(= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong under any circumstance. 
(= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong under any circumstance but Ann doesn't disapprove of it under any circumstance.          
(= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Each participant will be shown a set of 16 sentences, and for each sentence they will be asked whether they think that the sentence makes sense or not.

The 16 sentences are generated by taking the following 4 moral sentences (5)-(8) and coupling them with attitude ascriptions in the way above-described. 

(5) Murder is wrong under any circumstance.
(6) Volunteering is wrong under any circumstance.
(7) Eating meat is wrong under any circumstance.
(8) What she did is wrong under any circumstance.

The variation in the action under evaluation (murder, volunteering, etc.) is motivated by trying to make sure that participants' personal opinions about the types of action under consideration do not interfere with their judgment about the acceptability of the relevant constructions. To this effect, we include a type of act which is generally taken to be wrong (murder), a type of act which is generally taken not to be wrong (volunteering) and a type of act whose status is currently debated (eating meat); as well as an action token (what she did) whose details are unknown to participants.

q9.value: Sentences are presented in random order to each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk and will be paid $0.5 for the their participation, which will take 5 minutes of their time. Participants will be excluded if they are not self-reported native English speakers.

q13.value: We aim to recruit 40 participants for this study.

q14.value: This study is a follow-up to a study for which we had 34 subjects. We aim at a slightly bigger sample size because in the previous study we found more variability than expected in Moore paradoxes (which are arguably a control condition).

question.value:
Our study will manipulate two between-subject variables with two levels each:
(a) Person: whether the person to whom an attitude is ascribed is the 1st or a 3rd person.
(b) Attitude: whether the attitude ascribed is belief or disapproval.

We will expose participants to constructions and we will ask them whether they take each construction to make sense or not.

This will give rise to a single, binary variable to be measured: whether participants find each construction sensical or not.
Participants' responses, as they are binary, will be mapped into 0 ('it doesn't make sense') or 1 ('it makes sense').

We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results. We will run four analyses:

1) We aim to show whether the manipulated variable 'Person' is a good predictor of the acceptability of test items. 

To show this, we will do an omnibus model that tests the effect of variable Person on the responses, together with the effect of variable Attitude and of the interaction between Person and Attitude (omnibus model: response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude). 

We aim to see whether this model is better at predicting participants' responses than an otherwise similar model that does not take into account variable Person (response ~ Attitude + Person*Attitude). This would show that there is a main effect of Person in the presence of other higher-order interactions. 

Both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

2) We aim to test whether there is an interaction effect of the Person and Attitude variables.
We will compare the above-described omnibus model (response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude) with an otherwise similar model that does not take into account the interaction between Person and Attitude (response ~ Person + Attitude). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

3) We want to test whether paradoxical sentences in the disapprove attitude are below what one would expect by chance (below 50% of approval rate). 

We will subset the data to sentences in the 'disapprove' level of the Attitude factor and evaluate the effect of the Person manipulation on the responses: Response ~ Coherence +(Coherence|subject). We will use a treatment contrast coding with baseline for first Person.

4) Finally, if there is an effect of Person for disapproval-sentences in this second experiment, we want to see whether this effect is stronger or not than the one in Experiment 1. We will then test for an interaction between the Person and the Experiment factors, specifically for 'disapproval' Attitude (subsetting the data). 

To show this, we will compare a model that includes the interaction of Person and Experiment (levels: Study 1 & 2) (omnibus model: response ~ Person*Experiment) to a model that does not include this interaction but just the main effects (response ~ Person+Experiment). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure.

q21.value:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  

For analyses 1), 2) and 4) we will obtain p-values from a chi-square likelihood test comparing the full model to a reduced one in which the relevant predictor (Person or Interaction depending on the case) was removed. 

For the third analysis, we will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of selecting one response over other is significantly different from 0 in the baseline condition (for the first person), i.e., that the frequency with which participants say 'makes sense'/'doesn't make sense' to first person sentences significantly different from 50%. The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more 'make sense' responses and negative ones more 'doesn't make sense'

The intercepts for this model is predicted to be significant and negative: participants are expected to say 'doesn't make sense'  for First person evaluative sentences. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether responses in the Third person condition were different from the baseline (First person). This difference is expected to be significant.

q23.value: We don't expect any missing data (forced choice task).

q24.value:
In further analyses, we might want to look at another variable:
- Object-of-evaluation effects. That is, the impact of picking out different objects of evaluation for our test items. As explained in the design plan, we will have items with different types of objects of evaluation (murder, volunteering, eating meat and what-she-did). This suggests two parameters for potential scrutiny: 
(a) participants' knowledge of the act under evaluation (i.e., murder / volunteering / eating meat vs. what-she-did); and 
(b) participants' antecedent opinions about the type of act under consideration (murder vs. volunteering vs. eating meat).

A related issue for future work—which we will not explore based on our data but which it would be good to mention here—is the possibility that Moore paradoxes constructed with moral sentences ('murder is wrong but I don't think it is wrong') may turn out to be less unacceptable than Moorean paradoxes constructed with non-moral sentences ('it's raining but I don't think that it is raining'). Since we will not be testing the latter type of constructions in this study, this will not concern us. However, if our data shows that Moorean paradoxes with moral sentences are more acceptable than we would otherwise have suspected, this may motivate a further study targeting the role of moral sentences in these constructions.

We will compare the above-described omnibus model (response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude) with an otherwise similar model that does not take into account the interaction between Person and Attitude (response ~ Person + Attitude). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

3) We want to test whether paradoxical sentences in the disapprove attitude are below what one would expect by chance (below 50% of approval rate). 

We will subset the data to sentences in the 'disapprove' level of the Attitude factor and evaluate the effect of the Person manipulation on the responses: Response ~ Coherence +(Coherence|subject). We will use a treatment contrast coding with baseline for first Person.

4) Finally, if there is an effect of Person for disapproval-sentences in this second experiment, we want to see whether this effect is stronger or not than the one in Experiment 1. We will then test for an interaction between the Person and the Experiment factors, specifically for 'disapproval' Attitude (subsetting the data). 

To show this, we will compare a model that includes the interaction of Person and Experiment (levels: Study 1 & 2) (omnibus model: response ~ Person*Experiment) to a model that does not include this interaction but just the main effects (response ~ Person+Experiment). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure.

q1.value: Moorean and evaluative incoherencies: an experimental approach (Study #3)

q2.value: Andres Soria Ruiz, Nils Franzén, Mora Maldonado

q3.value:
Expressivists in metaethics maintain that moral statements do not serve to describe the world, but that their function instead is to express that the speaker is in a certain conative or affective state of mind. 

The contrast between moral and non-moral statements is sometimes presented as the idea that, whereas non-moral statements express cognitive mental states such as belief, moral statements express non-cognitive mental states, such as approval. Moreover, the latter express non-cognitive states in the same way that non-moral statements express beliefs. This is Schroeder's 'Parity Thesis':

'[M]oral sentences are related to noncognitive, desire‐like states of mind in the same way that ordinary descriptive sentences are related to ordinary beliefs—they express them. (Schroeder, 2008, p. 3). 

The Parity Thesis makes a testable prediction: if moral assertions express non-cognitive attitudes in the same way that non-moral assertions express beliefs, then whatever relations hold between non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions should hold as well between moral assertions and ascriptions of the relevant non-cognitive attitudes. In particular, just as certain combinations of non-moral assertions and belief ascriptions generate so-called Moore paradoxes (1), similar combinations of moral assertions and ascriptions of non-cognitive attitudes ought to generate analogously unacceptable constructions (2).

(1) Murder is wrong but I don’t think it is wrong.
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t disapprove of it.

Woods (2014) claims that this is not the case: sentences like (2) are not unacceptable in the same way that Moorean paradoxes are. He argues that this constitutes a major blow to the Parity Thesis. Woods, however, bases his claim that sentences like (2) are acceptable on his intuitions. But intuitions vary, and not everyone agrees with Woods on this score. 

The purpose of our study is to empirically test the acceptability of sentences like (2), and thereby provide empirical evidence that speaks to Wood's claim, the Parity Thesis, and the connection between moral language and non-cognitive attitudes that is the focus of much contemporary literature on metaethics and philosophy of language.

In a previous study, we tested the acceptability of constructions exactly like (2) (https://osf.io/vwekq/?view_only=d5281af405f54493a67cb3c2759d76ac). In this follow-up study, we will test the acceptability of the following variant of (2): 

(2') Murder is wrong but I don’t find it wrong.

q4.value:
We have two hypothesis: either sentences like (2') (henceforth 'evaluative incoherencies') are acceptable or they are not.  

To test these hypotheses, we will study the acceptability of statements constructed following this template: where x is an individual-referring term and A is a propositional attitude verb,

Murder is wrong but x does not A {that murder is wrong / murder wrong}

We will manipulate two factors on constructions that follow this template:
(a) Attitude: A will stand for 'think' or 'find' (thus the variability between assigning a that-clause or a different complement)
(b) Person: x will be the speaker ('I') or a third person ('Ann')

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong but I don't think that it is wrong.             (= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t find it wrong.                           (= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong.   (= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't find it wrong.                 (= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Given the type of constructions that we will test, our hypotheses can be spelled out more concretely in the following research questions:

(i) Are sentences like (1)/(2) significantly less acceptable than their third-personal counterparts (3)/(4)? In other words, is the Person factor a good predictor of acceptability of these constructions (modulo potential interactions)?

(ii) Is the difference in acceptability between sentences like (1) and (3) similar to the difference in acceptability between sentences like (2) and (4)? That is, is there an interaction between the Person and Attitude factors?

(iii) How does the acceptability of (2') differ from that of (2)?

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.
Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

question.value:
We have a within-subjects design with 2 factors: Person (levels: first/third) and Attitude (levels: think/find).  The combination of these two factors gives rise to four sentence configurations, repeated in (1-4) below from above:

This two-way manipulation generates the following four statement-types:

(1) Murder is wrong but I don't think that it is wrong.             (= Moore paradox)
(2) Murder is wrong but I don’t find it wrong.                           (= Potential evaluative paradox)
(3) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't think that it is wrong.   (= Third-personal counterpart of (1))
(4) Murder is wrong but Ann doesn't find it wrong.                 (= Third-personal counterpart of (2))

Each participant will be shown a set of 16 sentences, and for each sentence they will be asked whether they think that the sentence makes sense or not.

The 16 sentences are generated by taking the following 4 moral sentences (5)-(8) and coupling them with attitude ascriptions in the way above-described. 

(5) Murder is wrong.
(6) Volunteering is wrong.
(7) Eating meat is wrong.
(8) What she did is wrong.

The variation in the action under evaluation (murder, volunteering, etc.) is motivated by trying to make sure that participants' personal opinions about the types of action under consideration do not interfere with their judgment about the acceptability of the relevant constructions. To this effect, we include a type of act which is generally taken to be wrong (murder), a type of act which is generally taken not to be wrong (volunteering) and a type of act whose status is currently debated (eating meat); as well as an action token (what she did) whose details are unknown to participants.

q9.value: Sentences are presented in random order to each participant.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Amazon Mechanical Turk and will be paid $0.5 for their participation, which will take 5 minutes of their time. Participants will be excluded if they are not self-reported native English speakers.

q13.value: We aim to recruit 40 participants for this study.

q14.value: This study is a follow-up to a study for which we had 34 subjects. We aim at a slightly bigger sample size because in the previous study we found more variability than expected in Moore paradoxes (which are arguably a control condition).

question.value:
Our study will manipulate two between-subject variables with two levels each:
(a) Person: whether the person to whom an attitude is ascribed is the 1st or a 3rd person.
(b) Attitude: whether the attitude ascribed is belief or find.

We will expose participants to constructions and we will ask them whether they take each construction to make sense or not.

This will give rise to a single, binary variable to be measured: whether participants find each construction sensical or not.
Participants' responses, as they are binary, will be mapped into 0 ('it doesn't make sense') or 1 ('it makes sense').

We will use logistic mixed-effects regression models to analyse the results. We will run four analyses:

1) We aim to show whether the manipulated variable 'Person' is a good predictor of the acceptability of test items. 

To show this, we will do an omnibus model that tests the effect of variable Person on the responses, together with the effect of variable Attitude and of the interaction between Person and Attitude (omnibus model: response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude). 

We aim to see whether this model is better at predicting participants' responses than an otherwise similar model that does not take into account variable Person (response ~ Attitude + Person*Attitude). This would show that there is a main effect of Person in the presence of other higher-order interactions. 

Both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

2) We aim to test whether there is an interaction effect of the Person and Attitude variables.
We will compare the above-described omnibus model (response ~ Person + Attitude + Person*Attitude) with an otherwise similar model that does not take into account the interaction between Person and Attitude (response ~ Person + Attitude). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure. 

3) We want to test whether paradoxical sentences in the find-attitude are below what one would expect by chance (below 50% of approval rate). 

We will subset the data to sentences in the 'find' level of the Attitude factor and evaluate the effect of the Person manipulation on the responses: Response ~ Coherence +(Coherence|subject). We will use a treatment contrast coding with baseline for first Person.

4) Finally, if there is an effect of Person for find-sentences in this second experiment, we want to see whether this effect is stronger or not than the one in Experiment 1. We will then test for an interaction between the Person and the Experiment factors, specifically for 'find' Attitude (subsetting the data). 

To show this, we will compare a model that includes the interaction of Person and Experiment (levels: Study 1 & 2) (omnibus model: response ~ Person*Experiment) to a model that does not include this interaction but just the main effects (response ~ Person+Experiment). 

Again, both full and reduced models will include random slopes and intercepts for subjects, following recommendations  of maximal random structure.

q21.value:
We will use the standard alpha level of 0.05 to determine significance.  

For analyses 1), 2) and 4) we will obtain p-values from a chi-square likelihood test comparing the full model to a reduced one in which the relevant predictor (Person or Interaction depending on the case) was removed. 

For the third analysis, we will follow the standard practice for generalised linear models and obtain p-values based on asymptotic Wald tests. 

The p-value for the intercept will tell us whether or not the log odds of selecting one response over other is significantly different from 0 in the baseline condition (for the first person), i.e., that the frequency with which participants say 'makes sense'/'doesn't make sense' to first person sentences significantly different from 50%. The coefficient indicates in which direction: given the coding scheme above, positive values would indicate more 'make sense' responses and negative ones more 'doesn't make sense'

The intercepts for this model is predicted to be significant and negative: participants are expected to say 'doesn't make sense'  for First person evaluative sentences. 

The p-value for the fixed effect of Condition will reveal whether responses in the Third person condition were different from the baseline (First person). This difference is expected to be significant.

q23.value: We don't expect any missing data (forced choice task).

q24.value:
In further analyses, we might want to look at another variable:
- Object-of-evaluation effects. That is, the impact of picking out different objects of evaluation for our test items. As explained in the design plan, we will have items with different types of objects of evaluation (murder, volunteering, eating meat and what-she-did). This suggests two parameters for potential scrutiny: 
(a) participants' knowledge of the act under evaluation (i.e., murder / volunteering / eating meat vs. what-she-did); and 
(b) participants' antecedent opinions about the type of act under consideration (murder vs. volunteering vs. eating meat).

A related issue for future work—which we will not explore based on our data but which it would be good to mention here—is the possibility that Moore paradoxes constructed with moral sentences ('murder is wrong but I don't think it is wrong') may turn out to be less unacceptable than Moorean paradoxes constructed with non-moral sentences ('it's raining but I don't think that it is raining'). Since we will not be testing the latter type of constructions in this study, this will not concern us. However, if our data shows that Moorean paradoxes with moral sentences are more acceptable than we would otherwise have suspected, this may motivate a further study targeting the role of moral sentences in these constructions.

attributes.title: Model_User_Evaluation
attributes.description: Experiment evaluating how users write with an natural language generation model as a writing assistant.

q1.value: Evaluating end user needs in natural language generation models

q2.value: Tal Micah August, Nikita Haduong, Katharina Reinecke

q3.value: Generative models are becoming an end-user application: people are using these models for writing magazine articles or completing their emails. With this wide adoption comes the need to recognize that users have varied expectations and needs for a language generation tool besides coarse-grained metrics of coherence and grammaticality. We explore how users interact with these models directly and what they find useful about the models by observing how users write short stories with a generative model as an assistant who can provide potentially useful text for the user. We report on user behavior while interacting with this model and responses from users about what they found useful and frustrating. We investigate three realistic scenarios for writing: providing users with an outline to complete, a story to continue, or a blank page to write a story from and we compare how user needs differ for each. We propose new conceptions of what a 'good' generative model is and potential measurements that can capture these end-user needs.

q4.value:
1)   User writing experience will correlate with requests for writing assistance from the model (non-directional). 
2) Users  will  take  a  higher  proportion  of model  output  unchanged  when  writing  from  a blank page than when continuing a story or flesh-ing out an outline. 
3) Story quality will be rated differently be-tween assisted and unassisted writing tasks (non-directional)
4) Task difficulty will be rated differently be-tween assisted and unassisted writing tasks (non-directional).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
The study will be a three-by-two mixed subjects experiment. Participants will be randomly assigned one treatment condition (outline, continue a story, blank page) at the start of the experiment (the between subjects condition). They will not be told there are other conditions to the study. Participants will be instructed to write a story no shorter than 50 words both using a model and not using a model (the within subjects condition). All participants will be told that if their study is selected as the best story, they will be awarded a bonus cash prize. Before beginning there will be a tutorial on using the model to generate sentences. 

Participants writing behavior will be logged during the experiment. This includes keystrokes, time between keystrokes, number of times model output is requested, the original model output and the amount of model output used in the story, and types of words used from model output (e.g., articles, nouns, prepositions).

Following the writing participants will be given a survey asking how creative and coherent their story was and how difficult the task was. In addition participants will be asked to give feedback on what they enjoyed about using the model, what they liked about model output, and what they would have liked model output to include. Following this survey participants will complete a short demographics questionnaire that includes age, gender, native language, and writing experience.

q9.value: We will randomize at the treatment level by simple randomization (assignment participants into one of three treatment groups).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will recruit participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk with a screening requirement that all participants must have a >95% approval rating. Participants must also be native english speakers.

q13.value: We expect a sample size of 50 participants. Future iterations of the study will require 75-100 participants based on a power analysis (power=0.8, effect size=0.15, predictors=3).

q14.value: Current constraints are time and money, later we will collect more based on the above power analysis.

q15.value: Our data collection does give us full control over sample size.

question.value:
Writing task (all groups given a prompt): 

- Write a 50+ words story from scratch.
- Given a 4 sentence story, continue writing the story with 50+ more words . 
- Write a story based on a provided outline (4-5 bullet points).

Number of times model output is requested 
Edit distance between model output and eventual text integrated into story 
Keystrokes 
Completion time for writing the story
Number of times model output requested but not used
User self-ratings of coherence and creativity of completed story and task difficulty ratings.

1) ANOVA on each measured variable across each condition 
2) Chi-square test comparing number of selected word types
3) Chi-square test comparing model output taken in each condition.

q22.value: We will exclude any participants who submit exclusively model output or use only short (<5 words) sentences.

q23.value: If demographics survey at end of study is not completed, subject will not be included in analysis

q24.value: We will explore participants responses to what they felt was useful and difficult about model output to help explain our quantitive analysis of user behavior.

q25.value:

Qian Yang, Justin Cranshaw, Saleema Amershi, Shamsi T Iqbal, and Jaime Teevan. 2019. Sketch- ing nlp: A case study of exploring the right things to design with language intelligence. In Proceedings of the 2019 CHI Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems, page 185. ACM.

registration_responses.q1: Evaluating end user needs in natural language generation models
registration_responses.q2: Tal Micah August, Nikita Haduong, Katharina Reinecke
registration_responses.q3: Generative models are becoming an end-user application: people are using these models for writing magazine articles or completing their emails. With this wide adoption comes the need to recognize that users have varied expectations and needs for a language generation tool besides coarse-grained metrics of coherence and grammaticality. We explore how users interact with these models directly and what they find useful about the models by observing how users write short stories with a generative model as an assistant who can provide potentially useful text for the user. We report on user behavior while interacting with this model and responses from users about what they found useful and frustrating. We investigate three realistic scenarios for writing: providing users with an outline to complete, a story to continue, or a blank page to write a story from and we compare how user needs differ for each. We propose new conceptions of what a 'good' generative model is and potential measurements that can capture these end-user needs.
registration_responses.q4:
1)   User writing experience will correlate with requests for writing assistance from the model (non-directional). 
2) Users  will  take  a  higher  proportion  of model  output  unchanged  when  writing  from  a blank page than when continuing a story or flesh-ing out an outline. 
3) Story quality will be rated differently be-tween assisted and unassisted writing tasks (non-directional)
4) Task difficulty will be rated differently be-tween assisted and unassisted writing tasks (non-directional).

registration_responses.q8.question:
The study will be a three-by-two mixed subjects experiment. Participants will be randomly assigned one treatment condition (outline, continue a story, blank page) at the start of the experiment (the between subjects condition). They will not be told there are other conditions to the study. Participants will be instructed to write a story no shorter than 50 words both using a model and not using a model (the within subjects condition). All participants will be told that if their study is selected as the best story, they will be awarded a bonus cash prize. Before beginning there will be a tutorial on using the model to generate sentences. 

Participants writing behavior will be logged during the experiment. This includes keystrokes, time between keystrokes, number of times model output is requested, the original model output and the amount of model output used in the story, and types of words used from model output (e.g., articles, nouns, prepositions).

Following the writing participants will be given a survey asking how creative and coherent their story was and how difficult the task was. In addition participants will be asked to give feedback on what they enjoyed about using the model, what they liked about model output, and what they would have liked model output to include. Following this survey participants will complete a short demographics questionnaire that includes age, gender, native language, and writing experience.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will recruit participants from Amazon Mechanical Turk with a screening requirement that all participants must have a >95% approval rating. Participants must also be native english speakers.

attributes.title: Anticipatory pacing strategies in novel temperature environments: a systematic review.
attributes.description:
Does anticipation of high ambient heat cause an altered pacing strategy in athletes? 
Objectives: 
1.	The literature around pacing and environmental challenges 
2.	Anticipatory alterations in athlete pacing strategies that occur in response to future events 
3.	Brain interaction with physiological mechanisms and it’s impacts on fatigue

q1.value: Anticipatory pacing strategies in novel temperature environments: a systematic review.

q2.value: James Wiltshire, G. Lorimer Moseley, Kevin Norton, Samuel Chalmers

q3.value:
Winners of elite sport competitions, whether individual or team sports, are often determined by who can succeed in pushing closest to the boundaries of their body’s abilities in a given situation. The hypothesis of the central governor model is that there is a reserve physical capacity held during the pacing of an event to ensure safe body homeostasis (Swart 2009). It is the balancing act of pushing this reserve but limiting injury that guides sporting training regimes. Often an athlete is able to train for most situations they will encounter and can push into this reserve to attain greater performance benefits. However, frequently, an athlete will be confronted with a novel situation for which they have not trained. The hypothesised reaction of the central governor would be to hold a greater amount in reserve given the unknown outcome of the situation (Noakes, Peltonen, & Rusko 2001). The most common event causing the biggest effect on performance in endurance athletes in this situation is temperature fluctuations (El Helou et al. 2012). The implications of exploring aspects of pacing when confronted with future heat environments or novel environments is that aspects of acclimatisation, past experience, education and mental strategies can be improved. The primary outcome would aim to improve performance in athletes when confronted by these conditions. A secondary outcome would be to deepen the argument around the brain’s involvement in fatigue. The implications for this research will hopefully lead to further insights into the management of fatigue not just in the field of sports but in other health fields.
Although many studies have investigated the anticipatory nature of pacing strategies (Albertus et al. 2005, Tucker & Noakes 2009, Adams et al. 2016, Jones et al. 2013, Waldron, Villerius, & Murphy 2014), a preliminary search of the literature has shown only one previous study using deception of environmental and core body heat that reported the associated changes in pacing strategies (Castle et al. 2012). To my knowledge, there has been no previous research into anticipatory changes to pacing strategies according to future hot environments. The aim therefore of this systematic review will be to explore the literature with respect to pacing strategies, their interaction with hot ambient environments and to explore the literature around anticipatory responses to future events.

The objectives of this systematic review are to explore:
1.	The literature around pacing and environmental challenges
2.	Anticipatory alterations in athlete pacing strategies that occur in response to future events
3.	Brain interaction with physiological mechanisms and it’s impacts on fatigue

The following electronic databases will be searched: Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL); MEDLINE (OvidSP); Embase (OvidSP); PsycINFO (OvidSP); Emcare (OvidSP); SCOPUS (Elsevier); the Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews. Search strategies will use keyword and subject headings related to pacing and heat (displayed for Medline database). Reference lists of relevant systematic reviews and of studies for which full text was retrieved will be hand searched to identify any additional studies. Last, experts in the fields of pacing, fatigue and hyperthermic conditions will be contacted to identify potentially overlooked studies or those that have not yet been published. In addition to primary databases, grey literature will be searched, including clinical trial registries (e.g., WHO-ICTRP, ANZCTR, Clinicaltrials.gov), thesis databases (e.g., ProQuest, Trove), and conference abstracts. Grey literature will only be included in this review if the author can be contacted and data are available for analysis.

26.	Data extraction
Studies identified by the systematic search will be uploaded to Covidence (online). Studies will then be screened by title and abstract with unrelated studies removed according to the below tabled inclusion and exclusion criteria. Full text of the remaining potentially eligible studies will then be retrieved, and formal evaluation of study eligibility will occur. Two independent reviewers will complete this process; any disagreements will be resolved by consensus, or by a third review author if necessary.

Inclusion Criteria
Population
     Adult, human
Intervention	
     Endurance type sporting activity with event over 4 minutes
     Hyperthermic conditions (Temp > 29℃) (Tucker & Noakes 2009)
     Must show data on any familiarization trials
     Self-directed pace or resistance
Comparison
     Studies must have an effective control comparator in thermoneutral conditions (18-29℃)
Outcome	
     Study must include a measure of pacing strategy taken at multiple time points through 
            the course of the event
     Physiological data, a measure of perceived exertion, performance output (time taken, 
            speed, accuracy), Thermal comfort (Likert scale), Thermal state (Tsk, Tre/Tc)
     Ambient temperature, Relative Humidity (RH), Wind Speed 
Study Design	
     All randomised trials, systematic reviews and metanalyses will be included.
     Other study types will be considered on a case to case basis for deepening the academic 
            argument. 

Exclusion Criteria
     Fixed power output
     Population suffering any injuries or other limiting complaints
     Case Studies
     Partial body exposure
     Non-English language

A data extraction template will be prospectively developed. Data extraction will be pilot-tested on ten randomly selected included studies and refined accordingly using reviewers’ feedback. 
Data extraction will be completed by two independent reviewers; any disputes will be resolved via consensus (or a third reviewer). The following data will be extracted: 
•	Author; 
•	Publication date; 
•	Country of study origin
•	Study design; 
•	Recruitment method; 
•	Population demographics (age, gender, number of participants recruited/group); 
•	Participant athletic background (experience in sport, training level); 
•	endurance event characteristics (location (laboratory v outdoors), type, duration, distance, ambient temperature, humidity, wind speed); 
•	outcome assessment timings throughout race (Physiological data, performance output (time taken, speed, accuracy), Thermal comfort (Likert scale), Thermal state (Tsk, Tre/Tc). 
If data is not available in the published article, the article’s authors will be contacted a maximum of 3 times over a period of four weeks to obtain the missing data. If this is unsuccessful, the data will be considered irretrievable.

Other study types will be considered on a case to case basis for deepening the academic 
argument.

question.value: This is not applicable to the study

Included studies will be grouped according to the type of homeostatic event included (e.g., heat, distance, time, psychological stressors, etc.). If two or more studies evaluate a similar event type under similar conditions and for a similar distance, meta-analyses will be considered using a random effects model in RevMan 5.3 software. If similar RPE scales are used (e.g., Borg scale), mean differences (and 95% confidence intervals) will be calculated and pooled. If various RPE assessment scales are used, standardised mean differences (Hedge’s g) will be calculated. Heterogeneity will be assessed using χ2 and I2 tests. When χ2 has P < 0.10, statistically significant heterogeneity will be considered present; when I2 > 60%, substantial heterogeneity will be considered present. If sufficient data exist, a sensitivity analysis will be run.

q23.value: If data is not available in the published article, the article’s authors will be contacted a maximum of 3 times over a period of four weeks to obtain the missing data. If this is unsuccessful, the data will be considered irretrievable.

q25.value:
Risk of bias (quality) assessment
The Cochrane Risk of Bias assessment will be used to assess studies for selection, performance detection, attrition, reporting, and other potential biases per the Cochrane Collaboration guidelines (Jorgensen et al. 2016, Hartling et al. 2009). This judgement will be made by two independent reviewers, and disagreements resolved by a third review author.
The GRADE guidelines will be used to assess the quality of available evidence. This set of guidelines will provide a framework for rating the quality of evidence available and from this allowing for strength of evidence comments to be made (Guyatt et al. 2011). Two independent reviewers will assess each event grouping mentioned above for limitations of studies, consistency, directness, precision, and publication bias. The use of multiple reviewers will help to improve the validity of the implementation of the GRADE guidelines (Kavanagh 2009, Malmivaara 2015).  Evidence quality will be described as high, moderate, low, or very low using definitions prescribed by Guyatt et al. (2011).

q1.value: Grandiose and vulnerable narcissists' dating profiles on dating sites/apps

q3.value: Past research shows that narcissists are charming at zero acquaintance (e.g., Giacomin & Jordan, 2018; Paulhus, 1988), but little research has examined whether this finding extends to digital formats. This study will gather information about how grandiose and vulnerable narcissists self-present on dating sites/apps.

q4.value: Based on past research, we predict that grandiose narcissism will be correlated with being more likely to include information about goals achieved, exercise routine, and diet (H1a) and with being more likely to post at least one photo of themselves wearing revealing clothing (H1b). We will also explore correlations between grandiose narcissism and all other measured variables, without a directional hypothesis (H1c). Lastly, we will explore correlations between vulnerable narcissism and all measured variables without directional hypotheses (H2).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: After indicating consent to participate in the study and entering their Mturk worker ID, participants will complete the Narcissistic Personality Inventory and the Hypersensitive Narcissism Scale to measure grandiose and vulnerable narcissism respectively. Participants will then indicate whether they have used dating sites/apps, and if so which ones they have used and which one they used most frequently. Participants will then respond to a series of questions asking them about what kinds of information and photos they would or do include on their dating site/app profile, followed by a series of open-response questions asking them to write information for a hypothethical new dating site/app profile. Lastly, participants will answer demographic questions and be debriefed.

registration_responses.q3: Past research shows that narcissists are charming at zero acquaintance (e.g., Giacomin & Jordan, 2018; Paulhus, 1988), but little research has examined whether this finding extends to digital formats. This study will gather information about how grandiose and vulnerable narcissists self-present on dating sites/apps.

We will also explore correlations between grandiose narcissism and all other measured variables, without a directional hypothesis (H1c). Lastly, we will explore correlations between vulnerable narcissism and all measured variables without directional hypotheses (H2).

attributes.title: Presence of Gender Bias in Customer Reviews
attributes.registration_supplement: Pre-Registration in Social Psychology (van 't Veer & Giner-Sorolla, 2016): Pre-Registration

datacompletion.value: No, data collection has not begun

question2a.value:
We will randomly assign participants to two conditions: 2 Ads (positive vs. negative) as the manipulated factor.

16 different ads would be pretested on a positive(beneficial)-negative(harmful) scale.

question10b.value:
The first part of the study would be a computer based study. We will inform participants that their lab accounts are credited with a value of $5 for participation in this study. Each participant then would be asked to read a news article and answer few questions. The webpage with news article is designed in a way that participants would see 8 ads on the webpage. Participants would be randomly shown 8-ads, either positive or negative. These ads would be placed as online ads shown online. After reading the new article, participants would complete filler questions about the news article.

The second part of the study would be a retail study. On completing the filler questionnaire, we will direct participants to a room, which will display 8 different retail products. To make use of their lab credit of value $5, participants would be asked to choose any 5 of 8 products that they like. Their product choices will be framed as a part of their compensation. All the 8 products would be similarly priced. 4 out of these 8 products would be healthy or beneficial, whereas other 4 products would be unhealthy or harmful. These 8 products would be pretested on healthy-unhealthy scale.

question4b.value: Females would be asked to participate in this study.

question6b.value: In order, to have a high power study (80%), with 95% Confidence Interval. Power Analysis recommends a sample size of 95. We will open the study for 120 females, so that we hit the desired target of 95.

question7b.value: Participants who would not complete the entirety of the required portions of the survey will be excluded.

question1a.value: The influence of positive versus negative ads on female consumer's choice.

question3a.value: For this study, we will be manipulating positive versus negative ads. These ads are pretested by a sample to determine ads that are more negative (positive).

question5a.value:
It has been seen in past research that if biased reviews are used to provide recommendations in the marketplace, it would result in women being recommended less career-oriented products e.g. less online courses, job advertisements, or even less paying jobs (e.g., Bolukbasi et al. 2016). 

We want to extend these findings and demonstrate if women are more likely to be shown negative ads compared to positive ads, whether they are more likely to choose more negative products compared to positive products.

question1c.value:
Logistic regression would be used as the DV in our case is a count data (number of healthy products chosen). 

We can also sum up the calories of the products that would be chosen by the participant. In that case, we will run a one-way ANOVA.

question3c.value:
IV - Positive versus Negative Ads
DV - Total Calories of product choice
      - Number of Healthy products chosen

summary.value:
Project working title: Relational Deficits in Psychopathology: A Systematic Review of the Trust Game

Authors: Rebecca Kazinka, Iris Donga Vilares, Angus W. MacDonald
Affiliation: University of Minnesota

Protocol Summary:
Trust is a vital part of functioning in society, yet several forms of psychopathology have been implicated in deficits in trust, which greatly affects a person’s ability to build successful relationships. In particular, we identified five patient groups that are known to have deficits in social relationships, albeit in unique ways: Psychosis, Borderline Personality Disorder, Autism Spectrum Disorder, Social Anxiety, and Antisocial Personality Disorder. We will conduct a systematic review of papers in which the Trust Game (Berg et al., 1995) was administered to patients with the aforementioned psychopathology to better understand similarities and differences in trusting behavior. In the trust game, two players make sequential decisions about money. The first player (trustor) can choose to give some portion of a show up payment to the partner (trustee). The money shared is then multiplied by a value (like 3) and the trustee has the option to return any amount of the larger sum of money to the trustor. This game measures trust based on the amount of money a trustee is willing to send to a partner, in the hopes that the partner will return a greater amount of money. However, we can also look at reciprocity based on the response of the trustee. Further manipulations of the task have also looked at the changes in the game when it is played over several rounds with the same player (learning to trust), and the influence of background information (prior beliefs). Therefore, this paradigm can be valuable in understanding how relationships can be affected by psychopathology known for social deficits or relational disturbances.

A pilot search using Google Scholar was completed in October 2019 to verify that there is sufficient research available to assess the trust game in the different psychopathology groups.

The (estimated) start and end dates for this project are: 3/1/20-7/1/20

Full description of the pre-registration is attached in a document.
